metadata.case_name: Certain Industrial Concerns v. State of Uttar Pradesh and Ors.
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 327 and 363 to 369 of 1958

facts.text: There were disputes between the appellants (industrial concerns) and their workmen.
Disputes were referred for adjudication to industrial tribunals set up under general orders dated March 15, 1951 (G.O. Nos. 615 and 671) under s. 3 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Certain awards were passed by the industrial tribunals.
Appellants appealed the awards to the Labour Appellate Tribunal and failed.
Appellants filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in Allahabad High Court challenging constitutionality of s. 3 of the Act and validity of the two general orders of March 15, 1951.

Allahabad High Court held s. 3 constitutional but the two general orders invalid; however, orders of reference were special orders under s. 3 and valid, so dismissed petitions. Judgments: March 6, 1956 (Writ 967/1953); February 1, 1957 (Writs 51,523,524,607,632,633,634/1955).
Appellants obtained certificates for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.
Preamble to G.O. No. 615 of March 15, 1951 invoked cls. (b),(c),(d),(g) of s.3 and s.8, superseding earlier order; set up conciliation boards and industrial tribunals.
No recital in the preambles of G.O. Nos. 615 and 671 that State Government formed opinion as condition precedent under s.3.

Appellants contended no affidavit filed by State initially; State later filed affidavit in SC by Labour Secretary that drafts considered by Labour Minister, satisfied conditions for public convenience, order, supplies, employment.
High Court commented on absence of State affidavit.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of s. 3 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, particularly cls. (c), (d), (g) - whether excessive delegation of essential legislative function.
Validity of general orders Nos. 615 and 671 dated March 15, 1951 - whether lack of recital of condition precedent (State Government's opinion) renders them invalid, and if affidavit can cure defect.
Whether orders of reference were special orders under s. 3, making them valid even if general orders invalid (not decided by SC as unnecessary).

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 3 unconstitutional as delegates essential legislative function (determination of policy and rule of conduct) to Government re cls. (c),(d),(g); no specification of powers/qualifications/place for tribunals.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: In re Delhi Laws Act (1951 SCR 747); Queen v. Burah

petitioner_arguments.text: General orders invalid as no recital of condition precedent (Govt opinion for public safety etc.) in preamble; must be recited for validity, cannot be cured by affidavit; satisfaction part of legislative process.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Wichita Railroad Light Co. v. Public Utilities Commission; Herbert Mahler v. Howard Eby; Panama Refining Co. v. Ryan

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders passed without actual satisfaction of State Government.

respondent_arguments.text: No need for recital of conditions precedent unless statute requires; presume satisfied unless contrary proved; distinction subjective opinion vs. hearing/finding; validity depends on actual formation of opinion before order.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Bombay v. Purushottam Jog Naik (1952 SCR 674); Biswabhusan Naik v. State of Orissa (1955 SCR 92); State of Bombay v. Bhanji Munji (1955 SCR 777)

court_reasoning.text: Legislature performed essential function: laid policy (when Govt may act for public safety etc.), how (general/special order), what (appoint courts, refer disputes, incidental); details subordinate rules within limits; not excessive delegation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 3 lays down conditions, manner, contents; policy formulated as binding rule of conduct.

court_reasoning.text: Accepts State affidavit: satisfaction existed before orders; condition precedent fulfilled.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Drafts considered by Labour Minister; satisfied for public convenience, order, supplies, employment.

court_reasoning.text: Recital desirable but not necessary unless statute requires; defect curable by affidavit/other evidence proving satisfaction; presumption of regularity shifts burden if recital present; applies to subordinate legislation as to executive orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity depends on actual satisfaction and making order, not recital in notification.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes US cases requiring express findings post-hearing; here subjective opinion, no such mandate.

holdings.text: S. 3 constitutional; no excessive delegation of legislative essentials.
General orders Nos. 615 and 671 valid under s. 3; lack of recital cured by affidavit proving satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912
precedents_cited.relevance: Defines essential legislative function (policy determination, rule of conduct); permissible delegation of details.
Conditional legislation valid if legislature determines place, person, powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Purushottam Jog Naik
precedents_cited.relevance: Defective form in executive order curable by proof of validity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Biswabhusan Naik v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Omission in sanction not fatal if proved aliunde.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Bhanji Munji
precedents_cited.relevance: Omission of purpose in requisition order not fatal if proved otherwise.
Presumption of regularity; burden shifts if recital present.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wichita Railroad Light Company v. Public Utilities Commission of Kansas
precedents_cited.relevance: Required express finding post-hearing; not applicable here.
Statute required finding in record; hearing case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Panama Refining Company v. A.D. Ryan
precedents_cited.relevance: Section struck down for delegation; executive order fell with it.

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (U.P. XXVIII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged for delegation; upheld; authorizes general/special orders for tribunals, references if govt opinion on public safety etc.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ petitions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld constitutionality of s. 3 and validity of general orders Nos. 615 and 671 of March 15, 1951, curing lack of recital via affidavit; unnecessary to decide on references as special orders; appellants fail on argued points, appeals fail.

key_quotes.text: "The essentials of such function are the determination of the legislative policy and its formulation as a rule of conduct."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for excessive delegation from Delhi Laws Act.

key_quotes.text: "So long as a policy is laid down and a standard established by statute no unconstitutional delegation of legislative power is involved..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Permissible delegation principle applied to uphold s.3.

key_quotes.text: "...it is not necessary that the satisfaction of those conditions must be recited in the order itself, unless the statute requires it..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on recitals in subordinate orders.
